Posts.Title: Where are the December 2005 girls??? ladydi ladydi

Posts.Content: ladydi wrote: Does anyone know where this post went? I cannot seem to find it? Do posts disappear if they lay dormant too long? I would like to know how those ladies are doing! Dianne Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Where are the December 2005 girls??? ladydi ladydi

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 07:10PM ladydi wrote: Angie, I had bilateral 18months ago and I looked very flat... I did not have hills and valleys. I would ask your surgeon at your follow up to explain why. I too am "chubby" and had large breasts. Really, the only thing you should have left on your chest is skin and rib cage, at least that is what was left for me! I hope others will add their experiences. Congrats on taking your first look. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Can I go form-free after bilateral mastectomy? chemomom Erica

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 08:31PM ladydi wrote: Thanks all for your relplies. The nurse called back and said no, there should not be a problem... Just like you said, unless there is a fever, the show goes on. Ok, can I start getting nervous now? Only 4 more days without boobs!
Posts.Title: Help! A cold 8 days before surgery! ladydi shelray

Posts.Content: ladydi wrote: Hi all, I have a cold and am scheduled for billateral diep flap construction on the 18. I just came down with a terrible cold. Don't know what I can take for it, or what to do to knock it out sooner. Could this threaten my surgery? I left voicemail with nurse this morning, but of course I didn't here back. Any advice??? Dianne Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Help! A cold 8 days before surgery! ladydi shelray

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2008 05:57PM ladydi wrote: Also sorry you had to join us here. Many ladies are here to listen. I was 35 when diagnosed. I had a bilateral mastectomy. Really waking up after surgery the pain isn't bad. I couldn't do immediate reconstruction so I woke up "flat".  It took some getting used to. It wasn't always easy. But one year later, I had a diep flap reconstruction and I am on the road to recovery. Each stage, and hurdle can bring more tears and anxiety. Try to concentrate on one thing at a time and it will make it easier. Celebrate the little hurdles you get through and know that we are here for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2007 08:30PM ladydi wrote: I think the point here is to at least ask about them find out if they are available in your case and paid for from insurance. Scans saved me some headaches in the past as well.
